feed.title: Combined summary - Non-disclosure of a consensus bug in btcd

entry.title: Combined summary - Non-disclosure of a consensus bug in btcd
entry.summary:
The debate over the appropriate timing for disclosing security vulnerabilities in Bitcoin implementations has revealed a significant divide within the community. A particular point of contention arose between the `btcd` maintainers and two individuals, Niklas and AntoineP, involving the disclosure timeline of a patched security vulnerability. The `btcd` team advocated for a 6-month delay post-patching before making the vulnerability public. This stance aimed to align with precedents set by other full node implementations, which often opted for extended periods before disclosing critical issues, as evidenced by [Bitcoin Core security advisories](https://bitcoincore.org/en/security-advisories/). However, contrary to this cautious approach, Niklas and AntoineP favored an earlier disclosure, rejecting the proposed 3-month extension by the `btcd` maintainers. They argued for transparency and adherence to the initially agreed-upon disclosure timeline, emphasizing the importance of trust in the software's security measures and release processes.
March of 2024 marked the discovery of a consensus bug in `btcd` by Niklas GÃ¶gge and the author, leading to the release of [btcd v0.24.2](https://github.com/btcsuite/btcd/releases/tag/v0.24.2), which addressed this flaw. Despite the relatively minor impact on the Bitcoin network at large, this vulnerability posed a significant risk to `btcd` users by enabling potential attackers to create a hard fork via a simple transaction. A bounty was awarded for uncovering this issue, highlighting the project's recognition of the importance of external contributions to its security. The decision to go public with this information on September 23 was initially met with last-minute requests from the maintainer to delay disclosure, citing increasingly weak justifications. In their response, the authors maintained that without compelling reasons, postponing scheduled disclosures undermines trust in the handling of such vulnerabilities.
An analysis of the Bitcoin network revealed approximately 70,000 operational full nodes, with about 60 running `btcd`. Of these, 20 were found to be operating on versions known to be vulnerable, based on earlier disclosures by Niklas. Post-disclosure of the new consensus bug fix, 24 out of the remaining 40 nodes updated to the latest version, leaving 16 nodes at potential risk. This figure represents a mere 0.022% of the entire network, which the authors argued did not warrant an exceptional delay in their announcement. Nevertheless, they opted for caution, deciding to withhold full details until October 10th, while strongly encouraging all `btcd` users to upgrade to [btcd v0.24.2](https://github.com/btcsuite/btcd/releases/tag/v0.24.2) to safeguard against the disclosed vulnerability. This scenario emphasizes the ethical and practical challenges facing infosec professionals, particularly when balancing transparency and security amidst financial incentives and the prioritization of user interests.
